desc: The CBL gene encodes a proto-oncogene and E3 ubiquitin-ligase involved in the degradation of receptor tyrosine kinases (PMID: 11283727, 23085373). The CBL protein has several evolutionary conserved regions, including a tyrosine kinase binding domain, a zinc-finger binding RING domain and a short linker sequence connecting the tyrosine kinase binding and RING domains (PMID: 11283727). Together, these regions form a structure for binding to an E2 ubiquitin conjugating enzyme, which is essential for the E3 activity of CBL (PMID: 23085373). CBL family E3 ligases selectively and negatively regulate activated receptor tyrosine kinases, including EGFR (PMID: 23085373), PDGFR (PMID: 11283727), CSF-1R (PMID: 11283727), MET (PMID: 24384534), FLT3 (PMID: 17446348), through ubiquitylation that targets these proteins for degradation by the proteosome (PMID: 11283727). In addition to receptor tyrosine kinase regulation, CBL-b is also involved in T cell activation and peripheral T cell tolerance (PMID: 24875217, 17704644, 11283727).
articles/0/title: The ubiquitin E3 ligase Cbl-b in T cells tolerance and tumor immunity.

articles/2/title: E3 ubiquitin ligase Cbl-b in innate and adaptive immunity.

articles/3/title: The Met receptor tyrosine kinase: a key player in oncogenesis and drug resistance.
articles/4/title: Cbl: many adaptations to regulate protein tyrosine kinases.
articles/5/title: Flt3-dependent transformation by inactivating c-Cbl mutations in AML.

desc: CBL encodes an E3 ubiquitin ligase that negatively regulates receptor tyrosine kinases.
